clinical_study.brief_title: Injectable Collagen Scaffold™ Combined With MSCs Transplantation for Brain Injury
clinical_study.official_title: The Safety and Efficacy Assessment of Injectable Collagen Scaffold™ Combined With Mesenchymal Stem Cells Transplantation in Patients With Brain Injury

collaborator.agency: Affiliated Hospital of Logistics University of CAPF

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to assess the safety and efficacy of injectable collagen scaffold combined with Mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) transplantation in patients with brain injury.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of adverse events and participants with those adverse events
primary_outcome.description: Proportion of patients with postoperative infections and serious adverse events (SAEs) will be assessed by long term follow-up.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in functional outcomes as measured by National Institutes of Health stroke scale (NIHSS) score
secondary_outcome.time_frame: baseline, day 1-7, and 1, 3, 6, 12, 18 and 24 month after surgery

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in motor recovery evaluated by Brunnstrom stage
Change in self-care ability as measured by Barthel Index (BI)
Change in pain intensity as measured by Visual Analogue Scale (VAS)
Change in electrical brain activity as measured by Electroencephalography (EEG)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: baseline, day 1, 4, 7, and 1, 3, 6, 12, 18, 24 month after surgery

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in brain electrophysiology as measured by Somatosensory evoked potential (SSEP)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: baseline, day 1,4,7, and 1, 3, 6, 12, 18, 24 month after surgery

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in brain pathology diagnosed by Head CT scan
secondary_outcome.time_frame: baseline, day 1,4,7, and 1, 3, 6, 12, 18, 24 month after surgery

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Male or female，35-75 years old.
2. The surgery time should be > 6 hours after symptom onset.
3. Glasgow coma score (GCS) was 9-15.
4. CT diagnosis of intracerebral hemorrhage (25-40 ml), except for patients with signs of craniotomy to remove the hematoma.
5. Signed informed consent obtained from the patient or patient's legally authorized representative.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Glasgow coma scale of <8.
2. Patients suffering severe heart failure, severe lung disease, uremia, cirrhosis, end-stage cancer, coagulation disorders, stroke sequela.
3. Asphyxia, cardiac arrest or successful cardiopulmonary resuscitation before hospitalization.
4. Lactating or pregnant woman.
5. Refuse to sign informed content.
